referenced_tweets.text: It is a cliche to name a "genius" who "changed" music, listening or recording for everyone who followed. Often it is a bullshit honorific. I am however sincere when I say Alvin Lucier, genius, invented new ways to hear, execute, record and think about music and sound. Requiescat.

urls.title: Thea Ballard on Alvin Lucier‚Äôs I am sitting in a room
urls.description: FOUR YEARS AGO, the composer Alvin Lucier, then 86, performed his best-known piece, I am sitting in a room (1969), at ISSUE Project Room in downtown Brooklyn. Sitting cross-legged in a folding chair and sporting a Black Lives Matter T-shirt under his rumpled khaki jacket, Lucier read into a microphone from a hardbound copy of the score as if it were a storybook:I am sitting in a room, the same one you are in now. I am recording the sound of my speaking voice and I am going to play it back into the room again and again until the resonant frequencies of the room reinforce themselves so that any

text: We‚Äôre remembering experimental composer Alvin Lucier, who died today at age 90. Lucier‚Äôs work ‚Äúlong married scientific inquiry into the spatial and physical properties of sound with a humanistic sense of the poetics,‚Äù @tbird_news wrote in June. https://t.co/SpSs86oqz7

referenced_tweets.text: Its one of the most beautiful things to see in music or art of any kind, an artist putting their full confidence in a seemingly simple gesture that manages to contain multitudes and presenting nothing more than that.

text:
Doing so allows the audience to fully and deeply explore that gesture, to find so many new ways of being within it.

And no one did it better than Alvin Lucier. RIP to one of the greatest. Thank you for the opportunity to explore the worlds you created.
